title: Episode 117 – Michael Bronner, President of Dr. Bronner’s on Magic Chocolate
subtitle: ABOUT MICHAEL BRONNER & DR BRONNER’S MAGIC CHOCOLATE
description: Made from Theobroma cacao, or “food of the gods” according to the ancient Greek etymology, Dr. Bronner’s Magic Chocolate is available in six flavors: Salted Whole Almond, Salted Almond Butter, Crunchy Hazelnut Butter, Roasted Whole Hazelnuts, Salted Dark Chocolate, and Smooth Coconut Praline. And, as revealed in the “behind the scenes” footage, available exclusively to Y on Earth Community Ambassadors, new flavors are due out soon. Additionally, the special chocolate is sweetened by organic coconut sugar, adding to the health and wellness benefits of the special bars.
full_transcript:
[10.8s - 23.0s]: Welcome to the Y on earth community podcast. I'm your host Aaron William Perry and today we're visiting with the president of Dr. Bronners Mike Bronner. Hey Mike.

[23.0s - 39.6s]: Hey, how's it going? Great. How are you doing today? Oh really well. Happy to be here in sunny Southern California. Yeah, excellent. And I'm especially excited about our conversation today because we're going to be talking about chocolate.

[43.2s - 52.8s]: Yes, it's a it's a new thing for me to start talking about chocolate. Usually I talk about soap. So it's going to be fine. Yeah, that's great. That's great.

[53.8s - 70.9s]: Michael Bronner is president of Dr Bronners, the top selling natural brand of soaps in North America and producer of other organic body care and food products. He is a grandson of company founder, a manual Bronner and a fifth generation soap maker.

[70.9s - 86.7s]: Michael was promoted from vice president to president in 2015. His first directive under his new title was to promote his brother David to CEO defining the initials with an unconventional twist, cosmic engagement officer.

[87.5s - 97.6s]: After graduating from Brown University with a degree in English, Michael traveled the world extensively, studying in Ethiopia and teaching English language in Japan for three years.

[98.3s - 112.9s]: A philanthropist activist and active community leader, Michael is an advocate for many social and environmental justice causes advanced by the company, including fair trade, organic standards, animal advocacy and ocean conservation.

[112.9s - 126.1s]: He currently sits on the San Diego district export council where he counsels businesses on export processes, commerce education and advises per his expertise in an international trade.

[126.5s - 134.8s]: He was born in Los Angeles, California in 1975 and lives in Carl's bad California with his wife Aaron and their children Eli and Alora.

[136.0s - 146.9s]: Speaking of children, Mike, to kick things off here, for folks who haven't yet seen this, I thought I'd show and mention that this is the doctor Bronner's liquid soap.

[146.9s - 155.8s]: I probably have to confess that my mother once or twice in my child had had good reason to wash my mouth out with soap.

[156.6s - 163.5s]: When I keeter in on the fact that the liquid might be more effective than the solid version, we got a chuckle.

[163.5s - 181.4s]: Today, we're not talking about soap, something we might regret sticking in our mouths, but we are talking about chocolate and these beautiful, beautiful, absolutely delicious, new doctor Bronner's chocolate bars, magic bars.

[181.4s - 192.3s]: Mike, with that, if you wouldn't mind just kicking it right off and telling us all about why chocolate and what's special about your guys chocolate.

[192.9s - 197.9s]: Sure. What's special about our chocolate? First of all, it's absolutely delicious.

[197.9s - 203.8s]: You mentioned I have two kids, almost nine and almost six.

[204.6s - 212.6s]: We're talking about a rich dark chocolate that contains the finest ingredients from all over the world.

[212.6s - 233.0s]: We get our cocoa from Ghana and the Ivory Coast and our coconut sugar from Indonesia and vanilla from Managascar, but despite not having any sugar, but coconut sugar not having any cane sugar and being dark, my kids devour it.

[233.0s - 236.6s]: This is super indulgent chocolate, it comes in six varieties.

[237.9s - 242.1s]: I think our rising to the top are three pre-leain bars.

[243.0s - 251.3s]: We have a coconut pre-leain, we have a salted almond butter, hazelnut butter, but then of course we have a whole almond, whole hazelnut.

[251.3s - 257.5s]: One of my favorites, which is our salted dark chocolate, I'm a salted dark guy.

[258.9s - 271.9s]: It's been a blast, really, just getting this out into people's hands, getting people to get over their disbelief that a soap company is making amazing award winning chocolate.

[273.9s - 276.3s]: And yeah, just kind of spreading that joy.

[276.7s - 283.5s]: I mean, there's really when it comes down to it, I mean, you know, chocolates like love and a bite.

[284.6s - 287.9s]: Oh, I love it. I got to write that down because that is perfect.

[290.4s - 304.2s]: Yeah, and I will say that look, I'm an enjoyer of chocolate and have admired a lot of different great fair trade organic chocolate companies out there.

[304.2s - 314.2s]: We've even had one or two of those companies as guests on the podcast, but I have to say this is far in a way my favorite chocolate.

[314.2s - 326.8s]: And I don't know what you guys figured out over there. And I think magic is is apropos, but it's extraordinarily delicious and it's like a real experience eating it.

[327.6s - 328.2s]: Absolutely.

[328.2s - 351.2s]: Yeah, it's such a rich flavor. And you know, a lot of that comes from taking ownership essentially or oversight of all the materials that are in there in our extremely ethical, very transparent supply chains, many of which are regenerative organic and combining that with Swiss chocolate.

[351.6s - 351.9s]: And I think that's really a lot of the things that we've been doing.

[351.9s - 362.5s]: We've been doing chocolate years, we really know what they're doing. So I'd like to reaffirm to everybody listening that we didn't just take our soap making and say, hey, let's use the same technique and make chocolate.

[363.0s - 372.2s]: Now we worked with the experts, but what we really had was this amazing vertically integrated supply chain where we were already growing these materials.

[373.2s - 383.7s]: Because regenerative organic is it means that you're not just growing one thing. And so with our raw materials, we're already growing chocolate, all right, excuse me, cocoa beans.

[384.3s - 390.5s]: And already selling those to talk with tears. And so, you know, we just made the decision one day, like, why not us.

[391.1s - 397.3s]: And because we don't know anything about making chocolate until we worked with the best of the best.

[398.2s - 415.4s]: Well, I have to take the opportunity. It's not too often I get to enjoy eating something while doing an interview. I'm going to open up the yellow one salted almond butter here and have a bite my while we're while we're chatting and enjoy this love and a bite.

[415.4s - 433.2s]: And I thought I would ask you to kind of walk us through, you know, why for me as a consumer, should I even care about where the different ingredients are being sourced and how it's affecting people around the world.

[433.2s - 453.3s]: And you know, you put together this wonderful op ed in food tank.com called this world chocolate day. Let's rethink big cocoa in which you describe a bit of the history as well as some of the current practices with bigger mainstream companies that frankly are not practices.

[453.3s - 462.7s]: And I think this is I think we should be feeling good about. And could you kind of take us back to the the 1500s and kind of walk us through how we got to where we are today.

[463.5s - 474.4s]: Right. Well, in the 1500s, I believe it was in July, July 12th. I should remember world, world chocolate day.

[475.1s - 495.7s]: You know, they, you know, talk that was essentially first, you know, brought into the mainstream. It was, you know, called you know, feel broma food of the gods in Greek and it was derived for cocoa was derived from the Mayan word for cocoa or cacao from cocoa.

[496.4s - 515.1s]: And you know, it was considered to have these properties that literally cause feelings of love to emotes when you ate it, right. It was, it was very much an exp, you know, the promise of an expression of love that came out when you eat when you ate it.

[515.1s - 539.1s]: And over the years, you know, as chocolate made its way into the new world into Europe, it was kind of separated from its origins origins and the cocoa that was consumed in Europe was, you know, extremely delicious and with synonymous with Valentine's Day and you know kinds of holidays and gift giving.

[539.1s - 565.5s]: But the makers of the cocoa beans were just like not not even thought of and we're living in extreme poverty and we're using slave labor and there is this complete disconnect between the enjoyment of the finished products and the, you know, the tedium, you know, and the exploitation of the original materials.

[565.5s - 578.9s]: And so, you know, we want to, you know, we say this doctor Brian, you want to fulfill chocolate promise as an expression of love right and elevated into the pure indulgence it is meant to be.

[578.9s - 606.6s]: And in order to do so, you have to make sure that every single stakeholder at every step of the way not just after the chocolate, you know, gets to Europe forgets to America, you know, and this, you know, the cocoa is made into bars, but the stakeholders at the very beginning, you know, are being treated well are being elevated by the sales and consumption of the end product.

[609.1s - 622.3s]: And it's incredible statistic that struck me was the fact that only 10 per less than 10% of cocoa farmers actually have ever eaten a bar of chocolate.

[622.9s - 635.7s]: Oh well, you know, it's like, you know, they're harvesting, you know, this commodity for Western consumption and they never get to enjoy the outputs not to mention that, you know, oftentimes they are.

[635.7s - 638.9s]: You know, left and poverty conditions and can't make ends meet.

[640.0s - 659.1s]: And you guys obviously, we across all of your products are deeply engaged in a number of communities in multiple countries and I want to, you know, just point out and remind our audience that a while back we had the opportunity to interview your colleague,

[659.1s - 673.1s]: Garo Lezone with his amazing book, Chronicleing the Dr. Bronner's story called Honor Thy Label in the subtitle is Dr. Bronner's unconventional journey to a clean green and ethical supply chain.

[674.0s - 684.1s]: And in here, he shares stories about the years and the deep relationship building you guys have invested in in these in these communities all over.

[684.1s - 700.9s]: And I thought it would be good for our audience. If you could describe a bit, you know, what you guys are doing and how that contrasts with how chocolate is generally done with sort of the anonymous markets and clearing houses and that kind of stuff.

[706.1s - 709.4s]: Yeah, I'm sorry, you cut out there just for a second. Can you repeat that last part?

[709.9s - 719.1s]: Oh shoot. Yeah, was did you catch the part about the book? I'm sorry, I caught the part about girls book. I'm sorry, just that last part.

[719.6s - 740.7s]: Okay, shoot, we might have had a little glitch in the matrix there. Yeah, I was just I was hoping you could describe a bit what you guys are doing with the farming communities you're working with and how that contrasts with the mainstream practices with the anonymous markets and clearing houses and that sort of thing.

[741.9s - 761.1s]: Right, well, first of all, we're working directly with you know, and that's, that's the most important difference between us and big chocolate, right, because all those evils that occur in chocolate, we're talking about exploitation and child slavery.

[762.1s - 782.3s]: There's there's something called opaque by design, opaque by design, whereas there are, you know, pretty much five, five or so cocoa bean traders that secure all the most of the cocoa beans like 95% of the cocoa beans from all over the world and funnel them to, you know, the chocolate tears in the west.

[782.3s - 801.5s]: And you know what what you'll hear from like the nestles and the car girls is that, you know, of what we know of what we know and what we can track like we're going actually a really good job. I mean, whether they're not doing much, but at least there's no child labor or child or child slavery.

[802.7s - 830.7s]: And so, you know, the, you know, our call out to them, first of all, it's just like, no, that's not an excuse not knowing you need to go that extra mile, you're one of the biggest corporations in the world, you could, you could know exactly exactly who you're buying all these beans from, but they choose not to because, you know, the more you know, the more you realize that yes, you are responsible for exploitation and it does cost more money.

[830.7s - 840.8s]: Right, and they don't they're just responsible to their shareholders, not their stakeholders, right, and you know, the stakeholders being all those people all along the supply chain.

[841.3s - 859.7s]: So, you know, the first thing we do is we, you know, build relationships with local farmers, we build local mills, right, so the in Ghana, our project that we are using.

[859.7s - 889.6s]: Or using for cocoa is actually our palm, our palm mill, right, we have a regenerative organic palm facility there called surrender palm and it is entirely meant to show that palm can be generated in a regenerative way that you can actually grow palm and add trees and increase lightly hoods instead of taking away trees and just

[889.6s - 910.1s]: growing that crop, right, so just I guess first and foremost, when it comes to, you know, cocoa, it is actually one of the the crops that we inner crop with dynamic agroforestry amidst the palm trees so that we can a have better soil for soil fertility.

[910.1s - 940.1s]: And we can have all these symbiotic relationships, but also so that we are farming in nature's image and in doing so reducing carbon emissions and actually sequestering them into the environment and then, you know, very importantly increasing the value that these that these palm farms have for the farmers, right, so that they are actually getting more money.

[940.1s - 969.1s]: So that's really for all of the materials that are on there that are on there that are that is on our land and so you know the US like how what are we doing differently well for those farmers we actually pay a floor price right or sorry we we don't pay a floor price there is a floor price that is determined by the market, right,

[969.1s - 986.2s]: I'm sorry that's the market price determined by the market and then we will always pay 10% over that for organic another 10% over that for fair trade and another 10% goes into a community fund that then goes to benefit the whole community.

[986.2s - 1010.5s]: And you know we're training these farmers to you know not use pesticides we're actually training people who train them because it's always better if you have the right messenger, but we're developing expertise on the ground that can actually have these farmers build more value and you know in strength in their communities, you know we're building schools for them.

[1010.5s - 1040.4s]: We're building all kinds of development projects so that you know they're you know the children have opportunities to go to school better schools they have the ability to get paid more so that they're they're not there's not the pressure to bring in this house I labor and you know see we're giving them the the value added markets for all these extra crops.

[1040.5s - 1046.1s]: They're growing not just palm not just cocoa but other things like cassava to American gender.

[1047.3s - 1069.6s]: That's absolutely amazing you know and you know one little point I might add to about this idea of responsibility right and quote unquote not knowing is not an excuse and you know not only do corporations have responsibility but as I wrote about in in my book why on earth.

[1070.4s - 1088.6s]: In the chapter called demand you know as individual consumers we have responsibility to and I've been thinking about this the last couple days preparing for our discussion Mike obviously you know doctor Bronner's chocolate when I see it at the store may not be the cheapest bar on the shelf.

[1088.6s - 1117.1s]: I personally tend to opt for quality over quantity when I'm when I'm buying treats like this so I'm comfortable paying the premium but I think it's probably important that more of us become aware as consumers as folks sending the signals into the marketplace that when we're you know save in a buck or whatever on a bar of chocolate we are literally funding the child labor slavery.

[1117.1s - 1127.2s]: We have to be a pest use of pesticides destruction of ecosystems around the planet and I think it's really important that we connect those dots for us as as individuals.

[1128.4s - 1143.2s]: Absolutely yeah it's just like you know health care at home right when when when corporations don't pay health care right that that's those expenses are foisted on society and come out of taxes right and come out of.

[1144.5s - 1169.2s]: You know other other revenue generators and in these countries around the world that you are not paying a fair wage to for the farmers you know they are suffering they are suffering because the corporation even though they're able to charge a really high price for or excuse me a really low price for their chocolate.

[1169.2s - 1193.5s]: But they're doing so at the expense of you know farmers at the very beginning of supply chain getting pennies and living in extreme poverty and so you know when you're you're paying you know a higher price it means that you are ensuring that every stakeholder along the way is actually getting compensated reasonably.

[1194.9s - 1221.1s]: And not only are you guys at Dr. Bronner's really leading the way in your supply chain reach around the globe but you're also doing a number of really innovative things within your own company and you know we here at the Y on earth community are writing and sharing and speaking increasingly about regenerative economics and social enterprise and so on.

[1221.1s - 1237.8s]: And I thought it would be really great to have you speak just a bit about some of the mechanisms you guys have committed to within Dr. Bronner's that creates even more social equity and fairness for your whole team of employees.

[1238.6s - 1259.4s]: Sure well you know at Dr. Bronner's we cap all the executive salaries at five to one so the highest salary in the company will make only five times the lowest fully invested worker and then the fully invested workers is basically somebody who has been here for five years topped out at the wage scale.

[1259.4s - 1273.5s]: So the lowest paid worker here that has been here five years makes over $60,000 a year and there's nobody in the company that makes over $320,000 a year.

[1273.5s - 1294.2s]: And so what we're able to do there is we're able to take all of the added profits from the company and anything that's not needed for capital development or you know pay taxes is it goes to charity right goes to find all kinds of initiatives that we're passionate about.

[1294.8s - 1308.3s]: But for the for the employees themselves we also give them 100% non deductible health care for them and their families that includes a dental plan we also do Lasik.

[1308.8s - 1318.8s]: We also just started doing a psychedelic benefit where we offer ketamine therapy for a lot of workers.

[1319.8s - 1348.2s]: For all our workers and their families who wants to take advantage of that because these difficult times are just really trying on the mind and soul and we also give free lunches free vegan lunches for employees we cover the childcare costs up to $7500 per family through a really great program that even can work with.

[1348.8s - 1377.2s]: You know small scale nannies you know just individual nannies and such which is really been helpful during covid and we offer you know a profit sharing plan for all of our employees that's no different for people at the very top and very bottom that 10% of their combined salary and that's our combined salary plus bonus that usually 10% bonus every year goes into.

[1378.8s - 1390.8s]: You know a savings retirement account for them and they can access that when they leave and I have to say not many people leave until until the very the very last moment.

[1391.6s - 1408.8s]: It's absolutely beautiful and you know I kudos to you guys for really leading the way and setting the example for what's possible and i'll take this opportunity to remind our audience that this is the why honor of.

[1956.1s - 1975.8s]: So can you tell us also about the innovative work you guys are doing around the regenerative organic alliance and the regenerative organic certification I think it's a really important piece for folks to understand in terms of the stewardship of land and water and people and so on.

[1976.7s - 2005.8s]: Sure absolutely so regenerative organic is the combination of you know a strong social standard so you can say fair trade a strong animal welfare standard and a super strong organic standard but it goes beyond organic and I know that's controversial we say beyond organic but it's not enough to just not put carbon back you know in the world.

[2005.8s - 2026.6s]: So we're going to go into the air that there's a lot of legacy carbon already in the air and so it really encourages and and certifies like low till tilling mulching cover cropping ways of farming that not don't just put pesticides in the ground but are also like really bringing the carbon back into the earth.

[2026.6s - 2041.6s]: And you know this is extremely important because you know we hear all the time about how you know you know coal mines and cars and factories are belching out all this carbon into the environment.

[2041.6s - 2071.5s]: And you know close behind is agriculture right it's you know a phenomenal source of carbon going in the atmosphere and so you know we're trying to encourage away create a way for you know farmers to farm in nature's image and then consumers support that in the marketplace to create that circle that can really turn agriculture into a force for for climate change mitigation rather than.

And you know we're training these farmers to you know not use pesticides we're actually training people who train them because it's always better if you have the right messenger, but we're developing expertise on the ground that can actually have these farmers build more value and you know in strength in their communities, you know we're building schools for them.

Sure well you know at Dr. Bronner's we cap all the executive salaries at five to one so the highest salary in the company will make only five times the lowest fully invested worker and then the fully invested workers is basically somebody who has been here for five years topped out at the wage scale.
